column3: Description
Sequential numbering of each border crossing entry, used for sorting and reference.
Unique alphanumeric identifier for each crossing, encoding district, port of entry, and bridge abbreviation.
Official English name of the border crossing or bridge.
Official Spanish name of the border crossing or bridge.
TxDOT district or regional grouping for the crossing.
Port of Entry â€” the U.S. customs port associated with the crossing.
Geographic location listing the U.S. city, county, and state paired with the corresponding Mexican city and state.
Other known names for the crossing in English and/or Spanish, separated by pipe symbol (|). Includes historical, colloquial, and official alternate designations.
Classification of the crossing type: "Highway Crossing" for vehicular/pedestrian bridges or "Railroad Crossing" for rail-only bridges.
Detailed narrative about the bridge including its history, physical characteristics, ownership structure, and operational notes.
Year(s) the bridge was originally built, opened to traffic, reconstructed, or replaced.
Entity that owns the U.S. side of the bridge.
Entity that operates the U.S. side of the bridge.
Entity that owns the Mexican side of the bridge.
Entity that operates the Mexican side of the bridge.
Name of the road(s) providing access to/from the bridge on the Texas (U.S.) side. "N/A" for railroad crossings.
Name of the road(s) providing access to/from the bridge on the Mexican side. "N/A" for railroad crossings.
Description of how the bridge access road connects to major U.S. highways, Interstates, and the National/Texas Highway Freight Network.
Description of how the bridge access road connects to major Mexican highways and state routes.
Details about the U.S. land port of entry (LPOE) including ownership, construction year, renovation history, and facility notes.
For railroad crossings: lists major U.S. and Mexican cities connected by the rail lines. "N/A" for highway crossings.
Additional notes about crossing operations, typically stating that lane counts and hours pertain to U.S. facilities, and specifying toll rate vehicle types.
A notable fun fact or statistic about the crossing.
Internal review comments from Bridge Directors including factsheet corrections, historical date clarifications, name change requests, and update notes.
Internal comments from UNT (University of North Texas) or TxDOT referencing related Mexico-side infrastructure project codes and names.
